Overview
Data management - do yourself and others a favor
Digital data are the foundation of all scientific research. The increasing amount and complexity of scientific data – in terms of data types, file formats, file sizes and number of files – poses challenges to keep data organized and documented and to make them available for verification of research and new analyses leading to new insights.
 
The DFG Kodex “Leitlinien zur Sicherung guter wissenschaftlicher Praxis”, applicable since August 2019, emphasizes the importance of documenting research (Leitlinie 12). It encourages scientists to make research data publicly available (Leitlinie 13) and to archive data for the long term (generally ten years, Leitlinie 17). In 2017, the EU Framework Programme Horizon 2020 extended their Open Research Data Pilot to cover all thematic areas, making open access to research data the default option.
 
Data management involves data organization and documentation, secure storage and in many cases open data sharing. The purpose of these pages is to provide data management guidance throughout the research process, introducing MPDL tools and services to help researchers of the Max Planck Society (and their collaboration partners).
 
Tooooools !!!
 
Why data management?
It is good scientific practice, ensuring that research can be verified and reproduced. Moreover, data can be re-used – on their own or combined with other data – including in ways not anticipated by initial data creators. This can also prevent duplication of research efforts.
 
 
It is increasingly required by funding agencies and publishers. Funding agencies want outputs of publicly funded research to reach a wide audience. Publishers insist that data underlying scientific papers are made available.
 
Last but not least, it is in your own interest, for two reasons:
  • You can get credit for sharing your data, it creates additional exposure for your research, may lead to new collaborations, ….. .
  • It enables you to keep track of your own data and facilitates working together in research teams. Without efforts to organize and document your data, are you sure to find and understand them five years from now? Will your collaborators understand your data? You may end up being the first re-user of your own data. It may be necessary to re-analyze raw data upon request from e.g. your supervisor or journal reviewers, or even after publication if your interpretations and conclusions are questioned/challenged. Data loss could happen for many reasons and at any inconvenient moment such as the final phase of a Ph.D. thesis.
 
Data management does not imply that all data have to be shared immediately. Data publication can be delayed until after publication of research findings; sensitive data might be shared with a limited audience and only under certain conditions, or not at all.
What are research data ?
There is no straightforward definition applicable to all scientific fields – the broadest one would be “anything needed to underpin scientific research“, i.e. to validate and reproduce research findings. While physical samples may also be considered “data”, we here focus on digital (or digitized) objects.
 
Partly dependent on scientific field and research questions, data can be quantitative or qualitative, come in various formats, and are generated with a range of methods (e.g. field observations, experiments, model output, interviews/polls). Raw data are the initial primary results, processed data are the product of subsequent steps, e.g. data cleaning, quality control, data aggregation, statistical analysis.
 
Tools used during such steps – code, scripts, software if not widely available – are also research data. Preserving, documenting and – to the extent possible – sharing your data processing workflow contributes to research reproducibility (by others or even by your future self) and is thus good scientific practice.
Metadata
“Data about data” are equally relevant for discovery and understanding of scientific datasets. Depending on characteristics of dataset and intended audience, various levels of detail may be adequate. Metadata can cover the following aspects:
  • bibliographic information (title, author, …)
  • contextual information (subject, geographical location, temporal coverage, keywords, …)
  • administrative aspects (date of creation, file type, access rights, …)
  • technical metadata (file properties and file sizes, …)
 
Metadata can be contained in the file itself, in a separate Readme file, or on a landing page for datasets – preferred option for using search tools.
  • Dublin Core is a widely used generic metadata standard.
 

For discipline-specific standards, see

  • Data Curation Centre List of Metadata Standards
  • Research Data Alliance’s Metadata Standards Directory
